questions.question: When transitioning from a 1:1 model to a group coaching model (L1), what is the primary metric used to measure the 'Leverage Ratio'?
options: The number of hours worked per week divided by total revenue.
The ratio of student enrollment to the number of coaching hours required to deliver the curriculum.
The percentage of clients who achieve a positive pregnancy test within 6 months.
The cost of customer acquisition compared to the price of the group program.
questions.explanation: The Leverage Ratio measures how much impact or revenue is generated per unit of time. In group coaching, a high leverage ratio means serving more clients (e.g., 20) in the same time previously spent on one client (1 hour).

questions.question: In a Digital Product Ecosystem (L2), which product type typically serves as the 'Entry Point' or 'Tripwire' to build trust with a cold audience?
options: A $2,000 comprehensive fertility masterclass.
A $5,000 1-on-1 VIP concierge package.
A $27-$47 low-ticket digital resource, such as a 'Basal Body Temperature Tracking Toolkit'.
A free 15-minute discovery call.
questions.explanation: A low-ticket 'tripwire' product (usually $7-$47) converts a lead into a customer quickly, lowering the psychological barrier to purchase and establishing a financial relationship before pitching high-ticket services.

questions.question: According to Lesson 3, what is the most effective way to establish a 'Medical Referral Network' with Reproductive Endocrinologists (REIs)?
options: Sending unsolicited cold emails to every clinic in the city.
Offering a 20% commission for every patient they refer to your coaching practice.
Providing a 'Referral Feedback Loop' where you send the doctor concise progress reports on their patients' lifestyle compliance.
Asking the REI to host your marketing flyers in their waiting room.
questions.explanation: Medical professionals value clinical collaboration and patient outcomes. Providing a feedback loop demonstrates professionalism and helps the doctor see the tangible impact of your coaching on their patient's treatment success.

questions.question: When building a multi-coach practice (L4), what is the primary purpose of 'Standard Operating Procedures' (SOPs)?
options: To ensure the founder can micro-manage every client interaction.
To maintain brand consistency and ensure a uniform client experience regardless of which coach is assigned.
To increase the cost of hiring new staff.
To replace the need for specialized fertility knowledge.
questions.explanation: SOPs allow a practice to scale by ensuring that the 'proprietary method' of the brand is delivered consistently by all coaches, protecting the brand's reputation and quality of care.

questions.question: In Advanced Marketing (L5), why is an 'Application-Based Funnel' preferred for high-ticket fertility coaching ($3,000+)?
options: It makes the coach look more important and exclusive.
It allows the coach to pre-qualify leads based on clinical readiness and financial capacity before a sales call.
It is the only way to legally collect health data under HIPAA.
It reduces the amount of traffic needed to the website.
questions.explanation: High-ticket coaching requires a significant investment of time and energy. Application funnels filter out 'tire kickers' and ensure the coach only speaks with leads who are a high-fit for the program's specific outcomes.

questions.question: A 2023 performance analysis (L6) suggests that for a scaling coaching business, the 'LTV to CAC Ratio' should ideally be at least:
options: 1:1 (Breaking even on every customer).
2:1 (Doubling your marketing investment).
3:1 (Lifetime value is triple the cost of acquisition).
10:1 (Only possible with 100% organic traffic).
questions.explanation: A 3:1 LTV:CAC ratio is the industry gold standard for sustainable growth. It ensures there is enough margin to cover overhead, taxes, and reinvestment into the business.

questions.question: Lesson 7 discusses AI integration. Which of the following is an example of 'High-Value AI Implementation' in a prenatal coaching practice?
options: Using AI to write all personalized medical advice for clients without human review.
Using AI-driven sentiment analysis on client check-in forms to flag those at risk of burnout or high stress.
Replacing the lead coach with a chatbot for all 1:1 sessions.
Using AI to generate fake testimonials for the sales page.
questions.explanation: AI is best used for data processing and efficiency. Sentiment analysis allows a coach to proactively identify clients who need extra support, enhancing the human element rather than replacing it.

questions.question: When planning an Exit Strategy (L8), what is the 'Founder Trap' that significantly lowers a business's valuation?
options: Having too many employees.
Generating more than $1M in annual revenue.
The business being entirely dependent on the founder's personal brand and presence to generate sales and deliver results.
Using a CRM to track client data.
questions.explanation: The 'Founder Trap' occurs when a business cannot function without the owner. Investors or buyers want a 'turnkey' system; if the brand is tied exclusively to the founder's face and name, the business has low 'transferable value'.

questions.question: If your coaching business has a monthly churn rate of 15% in a 6-month prenatal program, what does this primarily indicate (L6)?
options: Your marketing is too effective.
There is a 'leaky bucket' in your client fulfillment or engagement strategy that will hinder scaling.
You should immediately double your ad spend to replace the lost clients.
Your prices are too low.
questions.explanation: High churn rates indicate that clients are not seeing value or are dropping out before the program ends. Scaling a business with high churn is inefficient because you must constantly spend more on acquisition to stay at the same revenue level.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes 'Strategic Partnerships' as defined in Lesson 3?
options: Paying an influencer to post a photo of your product.
A mutually beneficial relationship with a complementary service provider (e.g., an acupuncturist) to co-create value for shared clients.
Buying an email list from a pregnancy magazine.
Hiring a virtual assistant to do cold outreach on LinkedIn.
questions.explanation: Strategic partnerships involve 'co-opetition' or collaboration with providers who serve the same demographic but offer different services, creating a holistic ecosystem for the client.
